metadata.bible_text: 1 Corinthians 2:2; 1 Corinthians 1:24; 1 Samuel 16:7; Jeremiah 10:14-15; Isaiah 5:13-15; 1 Corinthians 10:12; Luke 5:32; 2 Corinthians 8:9; Romans 5:8
metadata.sermon_start_end: Good Friday is not for the faint of heart. It is brave of you to be here today. A few years ago when I was teaching at the Kanuga Conference Center in Hendersonville, North Carolina, I noticed that there was a new object there, located by the path that [...] What is Jesus doing on that Cross? Is it depressing? Is it frightening? Is it sad? Is it ugly? Yes, it is all of those things, but is it not also the greatest story ever told? That is why this awe-ful day is called Good.

1_specific_bible_passage.findings: The sermon fails Dekker's first thesis entirely. It is not an exposition of a specific passage but a thematic speech using a 'biblical keyword' (the Cross) and a collection of proof-texts. There is no 'recreating' of a single text into a current word; rather, the preacher jumps between nine different scriptures to support a general theological idea.
quotes: Paul wrote some words to them that mean a great deal to the Good Friday preacher: 'I determined to know nothing among you except Jesus Christ and him crucified'
Scripture says, 'The LORD sees not as man sees...'
1_specific_bible_passage.improvement_point: Select one pericope (e.g., 1 Corinthians 1:18-25) and extract what is unique to that specific text instead of providing a general survey of biblical 'perspectives'.

2_exegesis_original_context.findings: Exegesis is virtually absent. There is no mention of the historical context of Corinth, the linguistic nuances of the Greek text, or the specific theological argument Paul was making against the 'sophia' of his time. The texts are used as timeless maxims rather than historically situated revelation.
quotes: Paul was a straight shooter; he knew that the Cross was 'a stumbling block...'
What do the Hebrew prophets see when they look at us?
2_exegesis_original_context.improvement_point: The preacher must utilize their academic training (Hebrew/Greek) to explain what the text meant for the first readers before jumping to modern application.

3_application_concrete_contemporary.findings: The application is somewhat concrete regarding the 'zeitgeist' (obsession with image, plastic surgery, spin doctors), which aligns with Dekker's requirement for cultural knowledge. However, it often veers into general truths about 'humanity' rather than specific challenges to the congregation.
quotes: Why do the spin doctors stay so busy? Why are the plastic surgeons making so much money?
He sees us perpetually trying to divide up the world into good people and bad people.
3_application_concrete_contemporary.improvement_point: Move beyond cultural clichés (plastic surgery) to more specific, spiritual applications of how the Cross specifically 'expounds' the hearer's current life.

4_interwoveness_exposition_application.findings: Because there is no sustained exposition of a single text, the interwovenness is superficial. The preacher uses a 'sandwich' method: a quote followed by a contemporary observation. The hearer is not 'drawn into the text' so much as the text is used to decorate the preacher's narrative.
quotes: This is what Isaiah sees... Make no mistake, that's about you and me.
4_interwoveness_exposition_application.improvement_point: Let the movement of the biblical text dictate the movement of the sermon, rather than using the text as a springboard for topical remarks.

5_three_parts_misery_redemption_gratitud.findings: The sermon follows the structure of misery (sin/image/deception) and redemption (love/grace). It takes the 'misery' part seriously, which Dekker appreciates. However, the 'gratitude' part is underdeveloped, ending somewhat abruptly on the fact of being loved.
quotes: He sees a pathetic bunch of sinners trying to pretend that we are powerful...
He sees us in the full dimensions of our weakness... and he loves us.
5_three_parts_misery_redemption_gratitud.improvement_point: Develop the 'gratitude' aspect—how does this redemption specifically lead to a life of service or a new way of being in the world?

6_two_ways_seriousness_of_choice.findings: The sermon touches on the seriousness of being 'lost' in time (living in delusion/image), but it lacks the sharp edge of the 'two ways.' The ending is overwhelmingly 'safe,' emphasizing unconditional love without the gravity of the ultimate choice or the 'narrow way.'
quotes: There are those who will turn away from the Cross... there are many who call themselves Christians who can not or will not come alongside others in their pain.
6_two_ways_seriousness_of_choice.improvement_point: Address the reality of being lost more directly. If the Cross is the 'power of God,' what is the consequence of rejecting that power in favor of 'image'?

7_christocentric_grace.findings: This is the sermon's strongest point. Christ is clearly the telos. The preacher emphasizes the 'two natures' (Son of God entering the world) and the necessity of grace. Christ is not a moral example but the source of salvation outside the self.
quotes: The Son of God gave up all his divine prerogatives and entered the world to be executed alongside criminals...
Man has no life in himself, it is Christ who is his life. [Paraphrased from: 'so that by his poverty you might become rich']
7_christocentric_grace.improvement_point: Ensure that this Christology is rooted in the specific mechanics of one text rather than a general dogmatic summary.

8_depth_and_length.findings: At approximately 14-15 minutes, the sermon fails Dekker's 20-minute minimum. It lacks the 'breadth' required for true theological 'depth.' It feels like a meditation or a short talk rather than a full sermon.
8_depth_and_length.improvement_point: The preacher must expand the exposition of the text to reach the 20-minute threshold, allowing the scripture to breathe and the application to become more nuanced.

overall_assessment.summary: The text fails the formal definition of a sermon according to Dekker. It is a topical meditation on the Cross rather than an exposition of a specific Bible passage. It lacks the required length (under 20 minutes) and academic rigor (exegesis of original languages/context). While it correctly identifies human misery and maintains a Christocentric focus, it treats the Bible as a collection of quotes rather than a living Word emerging from a specific pericope.
strengths: Strong Christocentric focus where Christ is the telos and grace is central.
Adequate psychological insight into the human condition (misery) regarding 'image' and 'masks'.
Sober tone that avoids sentimentality regarding the brutality of the Cross.
weaknesses: Failure to focus on one specific Bible passage; it is a 'speech about the gospel' which Dekker explicitly disqualifies.
Insufficient length to achieve the necessary 'breadth' for theological depth.
Lack of formal exegesis; the preacher's academic tools (Hebrew/Greek) remain 'asleep' rather than being used to ground the sermon.
overall_assessment.final_judgment_according_to_dekker: This is not a sermon in the sense of Dekker's definition; it is a thematic meditation. It lacks the formal structure of exposition and application of a specific pericope and does not meet the temporal requirement for depth.
